content: Philosophical Musing on Burden of Proof and The Tu Queque Fallacy Why we suffer burden of proof for our current and past actions. Daniel Goldman Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 16 Photo by Giammarco Boscaro on  Unsplash Randomly, I swing and punch a person in the face. People are shocked. They ask why I did it. I shrug and ask them why I shouldn’t. If this scenario seems absolutely absurd, then you recognize that more than just claims suffer burden of proof. Actions are burdened by at least as high a degree of burden of proof. Why The Active Position Suffers Burden of Proof The concept of burden of proof is a fundamental component of protocol in debate. Unfortunately, there’s often a lot of misunderstanding of burden of proof, and as a result, burden of proof can be abused. All claims suffer burden of proof, whether it’s a claim of existence, nonexistence, or something else entirely. If we were to ignore burden of proof, then people could just start making any claim they wanted, and each person would have their own truth that would be incompatible with everyone else’s. But the burden of proof must extend beyond claims. It must include actions. For instance, if I claim that there’s a bug on your shoulder, I must justify that claim. If I hit your shoulder because there was a big on it, I would have to justify that action, with at least as high a degree of burden of proof. Gun control, the war on drugs, higher taxes, more government, regulation, and so on, all require burden of proof. They are the active condition. It requires force to enact these things, and in the absence of government, these things do not exist. They must be actively maintained . Therefore whenever there is a demand to add to, or even maintain, a certain level of governmental action, it is the person who proposes such things that must justify their position. If a person wants to push for more gun control, for instance, they must properly satisfy burden of proof, justifying the position that gun control works and should be utilized. Tu Quoque and Whataboutism If actions suffer burden of proof, then we can utilize actions in our discussions. The tu quoque usually involves referencing a past or current action taken by one of the parties in a discussion. Sometimes this action is a fallacy. But Tu quoque shouldn’t always be treated as a fallacy. Past comments and past actions are important. By acting, a person is affirming the validity of that action. If that action appears to violate the current argument then either there is an actual proof by contradiction, or the person needs to resolve the appear contradiction. It’s for this reason that whataboutism shouldn’t necessarily be seen as being fallacious either. A common example would be a person complaining about a politician for certain actions that they committed and the other party referencing those same actions having been taken by another politician. For instance, a person might criticize Trump for military actions that he’s taken and the other person might point out that Obama engaged in numerous abusive military actions. Unless a debate is supposed to be maintained in its own isolated realm of mental masturbation, it is reasonable to bring in additional information, including past discussions, past actions, and so on. Therefore it is reasonable to ask the person to resolve an apparent conflict between the current discussion and past activities. Now, it’s true that tu quoque and whataboutism can be abused. For instance, if the goal is to constantly try to come up with potential examples of contradictions and pressure the opposition to explain if and why they’re valid, then this process becomes a series of red herrings. The distinction then is subtle. If the example is common, and the person is likely to express the position, then it’s reasonable to get those few examples out of the way, before going deeper into a discussion.
title_html: Philosophical Musing on Burden of Proof and The Tu Queque Fallacy
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

Philosophical Musing on Burden of Proof and The Tu Queque Fallacy

Why we suffer burden of proof for our current and past actions.

Daniel Goldman
Apr 16

Randomly, I swing and punch a person in the face. People are shocked. They ask why I did it. I shrug and ask them why I shouldn’t. If this scenario seems absolutely absurd, then you recognize that more than just claims suffer burden of proof. Actions are burdened by at least as high a degree of burden of proof.

Why The Active Position Suffers Burden of Proof

The concept of burden of proof is a fundamental component of protocol in debate. Unfortunately, there’s often a lot of misunderstanding of burden of proof, and as a result, burden of proof can be abused.

All claims suffer burden of proof, whether it’s a claim of existence, nonexistence, or something else entirely. If we were to ignore burden of proof, then people could just start making any claim they wanted, and each person would have their own truth that would be incompatible with everyone else’s. But the burden of proof must extend beyond claims. It must include actions.

For instance, if I claim that there’s a bug on your shoulder, I must justify that claim. If I hit your shoulder because there was a big on it, I would have to justify that action, with at least as high a degree of burden of proof.

Gun control, the war on drugs, higher taxes, more government, regulation, and so on, all require burden of proof. They are the active condition. It requires force to enact these things, and in the absence of government, these things do not exist. They must be actively maintained.

Therefore whenever there is a demand to add to, or even maintain, a certain level of governmental action, it is the person who proposes such things that must justify their position. If a person wants to push for more gun control, for instance, they must properly satisfy burden of proof, justifying the position that gun control works and should be utilized.

Tu Quoque and Whataboutism

If actions suffer burden of proof, then we can utilize actions in our discussions. The tu quoque usually involves referencing a past or current action taken by one of the parties in a discussion. Sometimes this action is a fallacy. But Tu quoque shouldn’t always be treated as a fallacy.

Past comments and past actions are important. By acting, a person is affirming the validity of that action. If that action appears to violate the current argument then either there is an actual proof by contradiction, or the person needs to resolve the appear contradiction.

It’s for this reason that whataboutism shouldn’t necessarily be seen as being fallacious either. A common example would be a person complaining about a politician for certain actions that they committed and the other party referencing those same actions having been taken by another politician. For instance, a person might criticize Trump for military actions that he’s taken and the other person might point out that Obama engaged in numerous abusive military actions.

Unless a debate is supposed to be maintained in its own isolated realm of mental masturbation, it is reasonable to bring in additional information, including past discussions, past actions, and so on. Therefore it is reasonable to ask the person to resolve an apparent conflict between the current discussion and past activities.

Now, it’s true that tu quoque and whataboutism can be abused. For instance, if the goal is to constantly try to come up with potential examples of contradictions and pressure the opposition to explain if and why they’re valid, then this process becomes a series of red herrings. The distinction then is subtle. If the example is common, and the person is likely to express the position, then it’s reasonable to get those few examples out of the way, before going deeper into a discussion.

title: Philosophical Musing on Burden of Proof and The Tu Queque Fallacy
